Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Advanced insulated glass sealing techniques for low-cost, large area, flat panel radiation detectors.
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project will support the development of a new radiation detection technology with the potential to increase global nuclear detection coverage by at least an order of magnitude, while meeting important non-proliferation and homeland security budget constraints. Current radiation detection technology is too expensive to be deployed in large, discreet networks that cover global transportation pathways, cities, and nuclear storage sites. This project will develop a new product which combines a proven detector geometry (flat-panel multi-wire proportional chamber) with a powerful neutron conversion material (enriched lithium metal). By adopting expertise from the window industry, this project will substantially reduce the cost of these detectors via the development and demonstration of innovative panel sealing protocols.

The research objective of this effort is to design and test a flat-panel gas chamber body that adapts the hermetic sealing technologies used in electronics and vacuum insulated glass (VIG) windows. This sealing technology allows sensors to function in harsh environments: under water, in zero gravity, and in deep space applications. The Phase I work covers three approaches for lower-cost, high manufacturability chamber sealing mechanisms that will be optimal for smaller, robust chambers used in secondary markets (academic research, steel reprocessing, oil/gas industry). These sealing methods include ultrasonic soldering using flux-free solders, electrical resistance welding, and laser welding. Adaptation of this technology to neutron detectors will increase the robustness and reduce the manufacturing costs of the chambers. The expected outcomes will include proving out a cost-effective process to hermetically seal next generation gas chambers while maintaining high detector performance and durability.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Silverside Detectors’ goals for Phase 1 focus on the testing and prototyping of a novel design for a radiation detector that could greatly reduce the cost per count of neutron detection. 

We tested several key aspects of low-cost sealing technology motivated by the double-paned window industry, and determined whether the processes were transferrable to sealing gas-filled multi-wire neutron detectors. Such a design would enable a high-volume manufacturing of highly efficient detectors, then allowing increases in deployment of nuclear radiation detectors. This could transform the capabilities of both nuclear non-proliferation and safeguard applications, as well as open new markets for neutron detection such as advanced geological measurement studies and earthquake prediction. 

In order to attain this cost-per-count reduction, the cost of chamber housing must be greatly reduced. Low-cost sealing mechanisms used in double-paned windows have the potential to do this, but it was unknown whether these mechanisms were appropriate for maintaining the gas quality conditions of a proportional detection chamber of this kind. To this end, we explored whether the critical perimeter seals, as well as feedthroughs of electronic signals out of the detector, could take advantage of recent double-paned window sealing techniques to reduce the cost of the chamber.

A final goal was to apply the results from the testing campaign to create a prototype detector, demonstrating the feasibility of manufacturing a low-cost neutron detector.

Objectives of the testing campaigns focused on determining whether the materials used in low-cost sealing processes in double-paned windows could be used in long-lifetime detectors. Specifically, the concern was whether the materials would cause the gas in the detection chamber either to leak, or to degrade (i.e. the composition changes) over time. The key to a long product lifetime is maintaining a gas purity of 99%.

The main conclusion of these tests was that the double-paned window technology and materials (specifically Polyisobutylene, DP-460eg epoxy, and Stycast) can be used in a long-lifetime sealed proportional detection chamber. This is a critical result to enable detector sealing and structural components in a low-cost chamber housing.

The prevailing assumption in the physics community has been that neutron detectors are expensive and highly sensitive instruments, and the requirements for making them robust for performance outside of a controlled laboratory environment increase cost. This project has demonstrated the feasibility of making laboratory-quality detectors with low-cost components, which indicate potential for sustained performance in rugged environments. Demonstrating the potential to adapt physics instrumentation for low-cost, real-world applications, without compromising on performance, may set new expectations for wide-ranging application of next-generation technologies.
